properties.name: Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Limitations On Slavery
properties.source: "Liberties of Forreiners & Strangers": 91. "There shall never be any bond slaverie villinage or Captivitie amongst vs, unles it be lawfull Captives taken in iust warres, & such strangers as willingly selle themselves or are sold to us. And those shall have all the liberties & Christian usages wch ye law of god established in Jsraell concerning such p/sons doeth morally require. This exempts none from servitude who shall be Judged there to by Authoritie." "Capitall Laws": 10. "If any man stealeth aman or mankinde, he shall surely be put to death" 1641, in Colonial Laws of Massachusetts: Reprinted from the Edition of 1660, with the Supplements to 1672: Containing Also, The Body of Liberties of 1641, (Boston: Rockwell and Churchill, City Printers, 1889), 52, 54, 71–117.

properties.name: Vermont Proposition To Amendment
properties.source: "Mr. Olin, one of the Representatives from the State of Vermont, presented to the House certain resolutions of the General Assembly of the said State, proposing an article of amendment to the Constitution of the United States, to prevent the further importation of slaves, or people of color, from any of the West India Islands, from the coast of Africa, or elsewhere, into the United States, or any part thereof; which were read, and ordered to lie on the table," 20 Jan. 1806, in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 1, 343-344.

properties.name: Slaves To Be Sold
properties.source: "An Act to amend the several laws concerning slaves," 25 Jan. 1806, in Virginia, The Statutes at Large of Virginia: From Oct. Session 1792, to Dec. Session 1806 [i.e. 1807], Inclusive, in Three Volumes, (New Series,) Being a Continuation of Hening, (Richmond: S. Shepherd, 1836), Vol. III, 251-253.

properties.name: Bill To Tax Slaves
properties.source: "A Bill laying a duty on slaves imported into any of the United States," 27 Jan. 1806, in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 1, 273-4, 346, 358, 372, 434, 442–4, 533.

properties.name: Proposition To Prohibit Slave-Trade After 1807
properties.source: "Being satisfied that we are now authorized to legislate on the subject, I think it is expedient to adopt a permanent prohibition, and to make it a part of the present bill," 4 Feb. 1806, in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 1, 438.

properties.name: New Hampshire Proposed Amendment
properties.source: "Mr. Tenney ... presented to the House certain resolutions of the Legislature of the State of New Hampshire, 'proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States, so as to authorize and empower Congress to pass a law, whenever they may deem it expedient, to prevent the further importation of slaves,' or people of color, into the United States, or any part thereof," 10 Feb. 1806, in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 1, 448.

properties.name: Proposition To Limit The Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That it shall not be lawful for any person or persons, to import or bring into any of the Territories of the United States, any slave or slaves that may hereafter be imported into the United States," 17 Feb. 1806,  in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 1, 472–473.

properties.name: Maryland Proposed Amendment
properties.source: "Resolved, That the migration or importation of slaves into the United States, or any territory thereof, be prohibited after the first day of Jan., 1808," 7 Apr. 1806,  in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 1, 229.

properties.name: President Jefferson's Message
properties.source: "The following Message was received from the President of the United States," 2 Dec. 1806, in Annals of Congress, Senate, 9th Congress, Session 2, 12-16.

properties.name: Proposition On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "A bill to prohibit the importation or bringing of slaves into the United States," 15 Dec. 1806, House Journal, 9th Congress, Session 2, 482-483.

properties.name: Sloan's Proposition
properties.source: "And such person or slave shall be entitled to his freedom," 17 Dec. 1806, in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 2, 167–177, 180–189.

properties.name: Sloan's Second Proposition
properties.source: "Be it enacted, &c., That whenever any slaves shall be imported into this country after the 1st of January, 1808, if brought into a State whose laws do not permit slaver, they shall be free," 29 Dec. 1806, in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 2, 226–228, 254.

properties.name: Rejected Treaty Of 1806
properties.source: "Treaty of amity, commerce, and navigation, between His Britannic Majesty and the United States of America," 31 Dec. 1806, in American State Papers, 10th Congress, Session 1, 147-151.

properties.name: Bidwell's Proposition
properties.source: "Provided, that no person shall be sold as a slave by virtue of this act," 7 Jan. 1807, in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 2, 265-267.

properties.name: Section Seven Of House Bill
properties.source: "Importation of Slaves," in Annals of Congress, 9th Congress, Session 2, 477–478.

properties.name: Importation Prohibited
properties.source: "An Act to prohibit the importation of Slaves into any port or place within the jurisdiction of the United States, from and after the first day of Jan., in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eight," 2 Mar. 1807, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 9th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1845), Vol. II, 426-430.

properties.name: Slave-Trade Abolished
properties.source: "An Act for the Abolition of the Slave Trade," 25 Mar. 1807, in 1807: 47 George 3, Session 1 c.36.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Constitution
properties.source: "Resolved ..., That the Constitution of the United States be so altered and amended, as to prevent the Congress of the United States, and the legislatures of any state in the Union, from authorizing the importation of slaves," 23 Feb. 1808, in Annals of Congress, 10th Congress, Session 1, 134.

properties.name: President Madison's Message
properties.source: "Among the commercial abuses still committed under the American flag…," 5 Dec. 1810, House Journal, 11th Congress, Session 3, Vol. III, 433-436.

properties.name: Secret Act And Joint Resolution Against Amelia Island Smugglers
properties.source: "Relative to the Occupation of the Floridas by the United States of America," 15 Jan. 1811, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 11th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1845), Vol. III, 471.

properties.name: Treaty Of Ghent
properties.source: "Treaty of peace and amity, Concluded Dec. 24, 1814; Ratifications exchanged at Washington February 17, 1815; Proclaimed February 18, 1815," 18 Feb. 1815, in The Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America, from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, (Boston: Little, Brown, and Company, 1867), Vol. VIII, 218-223.

properties.name: French Abolition Of The Slave-Trade
properties.source: “Napoleon’s Decree Abolishing the Slave Trade, 1815,” 29 Mar. 1815, in Great Britain and Foreign Commonwealth Office, British and Foreign State Papers 1815-1816, (London: James Ridgway and Sons, Piccadilly, 1838), Vol. III, 196.

properties.name: Act To Dispose Of Illegally Imported Slaves
properties.source: "An Act concerning Slaves brought into this Territory, contrary to the Laws of the United States," 8 Dec. 1815, in Alabama and Harry Toulmin, A Digest of the Laws of the State of Alabama: Containing the Statutes and Resolutions in Force at the End of the General Assembly in Jan., 1823: To Which Is Added an Appendix, (Cahawba: Ginn & Curtis, 1828), 637.

properties.name: Act To Dispose Of Illegally Imported Slaves
properties.source: "An act to direct the disposal of negroes, mulattoes and persons of colour, imported into this state, contrary to the provisions of an act of the Congress of the United States," 18 Nov. 1816, in North Carolina, Laws of the State of North-Carolina: Including the Titles of Such Statutes and Parts of Statutes of Great Britain as Are in Force in Said State; Together with the Second Charter Granted by Charles II. to the Proprietors of Carolina; the Great Deed of Grant from the Lords Proprietors; the Grant from George II. to John Lord Granville; the Bill of Rights and Constitution of the State, Including the Names of the Members of the Convention That Formed the Same; the Constitution of the United States, with the Amendments; and the Treaty of Peace of 1783; with Marginal Notes and References (Raleigh: J. Gales, 1821), Vol. II, 1350-1353.

properties.name: President Madison's Message
properties.source: "The United States having been the first to abolish, within the extent of their authority, the transportation of the natives of Africa into slavery, by prohibiting the introduction of slaves, and by punishing their citizens participating in the traffick, cannot but be gratified at the progress, made by concurrent efforts of other nations, towards a general suppression of so great an evil," 3 Dec. 1816, in House Journal, 14th Congress, Session 2, 9–21.

properties.name: Act To Prohibit Importation Of Slaves Into The State
properties.source: "An Act to prohibit the importation of Slaves from any of the United States and for other purposes therin mentioned," 19 Dec. 1816, in Thomas Cooper (eds.), Statutes at Large of South Carolina, (Columnbia: A.S. Johnson, 1840), Vol. VII, 451-454.

properties.name: Proposed Joint Resolution
properties.source: "Joint Resolution for abolishing the traffick in Slaves, and the Colinization of the Free People of Colour of the United States," 11 Feb. 1817, in John Pendleton Kennedy, United States Congress House Committee on Commerce and John Pendleton Kennedy, Report of Mr. Kennedy, of Maryland, from the Committee on Commerce of the House of Representatives of the United States: On the Memorial of the Friends of African Colonization, Assembled in Convention in the City of Washington, May, 1842: To Which Is Appended, a Collection of the Most Interesting Papers on the Subject of African Colonization, and the Commerce, Etc., of Western Africa, Together with All the Diplomatic Correspondence Between the United States and Great Britain, on the Subject of the African Slave Trade (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1843), 213.

properties.name: First Concession Of Right Of Search
properties.source: "By this treaty, ships of war of each of the nations might visit merchant vessels of both, if suspected of having slaves on board, acquired by illicit traffic." This "related only to the trade north of the equator; for the slave-trade of Portugal within the regions of western Africa, to the south of the equator, continued long after this to be carried on with great vigor," in Great Britain Foreign and Commonwealth Office, British and Foreign State Papers, 1816-1817 (London: H.M. Stationery Office, 1838), 85-118.

properties.name: Abolition of Trade North of the Equator
properties.source: "By the treaty of Madrid, ... Great Britain obtained from Spain, for the sum of four hundred thousand pounds, the immediate abolition of the trade north of the equator, its entire abolition after 1820, and the concession of the same mutual right of search, which the treaty with Portugal had just established," 23 Sep. 1817, in Great Britain Foreign and Commonwealth Office, British and Foreign State Papers, 1816-1817 (London: H.M. Stationery Office, 1838), 33-74.

properties.name: President Monroe's Message On Amelia Island
properties.source: "A just regard for the rights and interests of the United States required that they should be suppressed, and orders have been accordingly issued to that effect," 2 Dec. 1817, in House Journal, 15th Congress, Session 1, 11.

properties.name: Act To Dispose Of Illegally Imported Slaves
properties.source: "An Act for disposing of any such negro, mulatto, or person of color, who has been or may hereafter be imported or brought into this State in violation of an act of the United States, entitled an act to prohibit the importation of slaves," 19 Dec. 1817, in Oliver Hillhouse Prince, A Digest of the Laws of the State of Georgia: Containing All Statutes and the Substance of All Resolutions of a General and Public Nature, and Now in Force, Which Have Been Passed in This State, Previous to the Session of the General Assembly of Dec., 1820 (Savannah: Grantland & Orme, 1822), 463.

properties.name: Bill To Supplement Act Of 1807
properties.source: "Mr. Middleton reported a bill supplementary to the act, entitled 'An act to prohibit the importation of slaves into any port or place within the jurisdiction of the United States;'" 10 Jan. 1818, House Journal, 15th Congress, Session 1, 131, 410.

properties.name: President Monroe's Special Message To Congress
properties.source: "I have the satisfaction to inform Congress, that the establishment at Amelia Island has been suppressed, and without the effusion of blood," 13 Jan. 1818, in House Journal, 15th Congress, Session 1,  in “A Century of Lawmaking for a New Nation: U.S. Congressional Documents and Debates, 1774 - 1875,” Library of Congress, 137-139.

properties.name: Bill For Registering Slaves
properties.source: "A bill respecting the transportation of persons of color, for sale, or to be held to labor," 9 Feb. 1818, in Senate Journal, 15th Congress, Session 1, 147.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Constitution
properties.source: "No person shall be held to service or labour as a slave, nor shall slavery be tolerated in any state hereafter admitted into the Union, or made one of the United States of America," 4 Apr. 1818, in Annals of Congress, 15th Congress, Session 1, 1675–1676.

properties.name: Act In Addition To Act Of 1807
properties.source: "An Act in addition to 'An act to prohibit the introduction of slaves into any port or place within the jurisdiction of the United States, from and after the first day of Jan., in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eight,' and to repeal certain parts of the same," 20 Apr. 1818, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 15th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1845), Vol. III, 450-453.

properties.name: Great Britain And Netherlands Treaty
properties.source: "Treaty between His Britannic Majesty and his Majesty the King of the Netherlands for preventing their Subjects from engaging in the Traffic in Slaves," 4 May 1818, in Great Britain Foreign and Commonwealth Office, British and Foreign State Papers, 1816-1817 (London: H.M. Stationery Office, 1838), 125-143.

properties.name: Act Of 1817 Reinforced
properties.source: "Whereas numbers of African slaves have been illegally introduced into the State, in direct violation of the laws of the United States and of this State," 19 Dec. 1818, in Oliver Hillhouse Prince, A Digest of the Laws of the State of Georgia: Containing All Statutes and the Substance of All Resolutions of a General and Public Nature, and Now in Force, Which Have Been Passed in This State, Previous to the Session of the General Assembly of Dec., 1820 (Savannah: Grantland & Orme, 1822), 469.

properties.name: A Bill In Addition To Former Acts
properties.source: "A bill supplementary to an act, passed the 2d day of Mar., 1807, entitled," 8 Feb. 1819, in Senate Journal, 15th Congress, Session 2, 234, 244, 311–312, 347.

properties.name: Cruisers Authorized
properties.source: "An Act in addition to the Acts prohibiting the slave trade," 3 Mar. 1819, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 15th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1845), Vol. III, 532-534.

properties.name: President Monroe's Message
properties.source: "Orders have been given to the commanders of all our public ships to seize all vessels navigated under our flag, engaged in that trade, and to bring them in, to be proceeded against, in the manner prescribed by that law," 7 Dec. 1819, in House Journal, 16th Congress, Session 1, 9-18.

properties.name: Proposed Registry Of Slaves
properties.source: "Resolved, That the Committee on the Slave Trade be instructed to enquire into the expediency of establishing a registry of slaves, more effectually to prevent the importation of slaves into the United States, or the territories thereof," 9 Jan. 1820, House Journal, 16th Congress, Session 1, 150.

properties.name: Mr. Meigs's Proposition On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Whereas, slavery in the United States is an evil of great and increasing magnitude; one which merits the greatest efforts of this nation to remedy," 5 Feb. 1820, House Journal, 16th Congress, Session 1, 196, 200, 227.

properties.name: Slavery In Western Territory
properties.source: "Resolve respecting Slavery," 23 Feb. 1820, in Massachusetts, Acts and Resolves Passed by the General Court of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Passed at Several Sessions of the General Court, Commencing May 1819, and Ending February 21, 1824 (Boston: True and Greene, 1824), 147–151.

properties.name: Resolution For Negotiation
properties.source: "Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, That the President of the United States be requested to negociate with all the governments where ministers of the United States are or shall be accredited, on the means of effecting an entire and immediate abolition of the slave trade," 12 May 1820, in Annals of Congress, 16th Congress, Session 1, 697–700.

properties.name: Slave-Trade Made Piracy
properties.source: "An act to continue in force 'An act to protect the commerce of the United States, and punish the crime of piracy,' and also to make further provisions for punishing the crime of piracy," 15 May, 1820, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 16th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. VII, 600-601.

properties.name: President Monroe's Message
properties.source: "In execution of the law of the last session, for the suppression of the slave trade, some of our public ships have also been employed on the coast of Africa, where several captures have already been made of vessels engaged in that disgraceful traffic," 14 Nov. 1820, in Senate Journal, 16th Congress, Session 2, 8–17.

properties.name: Meigs's Resolution
properties.source: "Whereas slavery, in the United States, is an evil, acknowledged to be of great and increasing magnitude, ...," 15 Feb. 1821, in Annals of Congress, 16th Congress, Session 2, 1168–70.

properties.name: President Monroe's Message
properties.source: "Like success has attended our efforts to suppress the slave trade," 3 Dec. 1821, in  House Journal, 17th Congress, Session 1, 11-22.

properties.name: Proposed Resolution
properties.source: "Resolved, That the President of the United States be requested to enter into such arrangements as he may deem suitable and proper, with one or more of the maritime powers of Europe, for the effectual abolition of the slave trade," 12 Apr. 1822, in Annals of Congress, 17th Congress, Session 1, 1538.

properties.name: Act On Importation
properties.source: "An act, to reduce into one, the several acts, concerning slaves, free negroes, and mulattoes," 18 Jun. 1822, in Laws of the State of Mississippi: Embracing All Acts of a Public Nature from Jan. Session, 1824, to Jan. Session, 1838, Inclusive (Jackson: John D. Toy, 1838), 349-353.

properties.name: President Monroe's Message
properties.source: "A cruise has also been maintained on the coast of Africa, when the season would permit, for the suppression of the slave-trade; and orders have been given to the commanders of all our public ships to seize our own vessels, should they find any engaged in that trade, and to bring them in for adjudication," 3 Dec. 1822, in House Journal, 17th Congress, Session 2, 8-18, 21.

properties.name: Act To Dispose Of Illegally Imported Slaves
properties.source: "An Act to carry into effect the laws of the United States prohibiting the slave trade," 1 Jan. 1823, in Alabama Legislature, Alabama Legislative Acts, 1822-1823, (Cahawba: W. M. B. Allen and Co., 1823), 62-63.

properties.name: Piracy Act Made Perpetual
properties.source: "An Act in addition to 'An act to continue in force "An act to protect the commerce of the United States, and punish the crime of piracy,'" 30 Jan. 1823, in House Journal, 17th Congress, Session 2, 73, 76, 156, 183, 189.

properties.name: Resolution On The Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That the President of the United States be requested to enter upon, and to prosecute, from time to time, such negotiations with the several maritime powers of Europe and America, as he may deem expedient, for the effectual abolition of the African slave trade, and its ultimate denunciation as piracy, under the law of nations, by the consent of the civilized world," 10 Feb. 1823, in Annals of Congress, 17th Congress, Session 2, 928, 1147–1151.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the support of the navy," 3 Mar. 1823, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 17th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1845), Vol. III, 763-764.

properties.name: Proposed Treaty With Spain
properties.source: "Extract of a letter From Mr. Adams to Mr. Nelson," 24 Apr. 1823, in Annals of Congress, 18th Congress, Session 1, 3016.

properties.name: Proposed Treaty With Buenos Ayres
properties.source: "Extract of a letter From Mr. Adams to Mr. Rodney," 17 May 1823, in Annals of Congress, 18th Congress, Session 1, 3016.

properties.name: Proposed Treaty With The United States Of Colombia
properties.source: "Extract from the General Instructions to Richard C. Anderson, appointed Minister Plenipotentiary to the Republic of Colombia" 27 May 1823, in Annals of Congress, 18th Congress, Session 1, 3016-3017.

properties.name: Proposed Treaty
properties.source: "A Convention for the Supression of Piracy, committed by the African Slave Trade," 24 Jun. 1823, in Joseph Gales, The Debates and Proceedings in the Congress of the United States: With an Appendix, Containing Important State Papers and Public Documents, and All the Laws of a Public Nature; with a Copious Index (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1824), 3022-3027.

properties.name: Proposed Treaty With Portugal
properties.source: "Extracts of a letter (No. 6) from Mr. Adams to General Dearborn, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary  of the United States, at Libson," 1823, in Annals of Congress, 18th Congress, Session 1, 3030-3031.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Constitution
properties.source: "That no part of the constitution of the United States ought to be construed, or shall be construed to authorize the importation or ingress of any person of color into any one of the United States, contrary to the laws of such state," 6 Feb. 1824, in Annals of Congress, 18th Congress, Session 1, 1399.

properties.name: Proposed Treaty Of 1824
properties.source: "The Convention," 13 Mar. 1824, in United States Congress, American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1858), 319-322.

properties.name: Slave-Trade Made Piracy
properties.source: "An Act for the more effectual Suppression of the African Slave Trade," 31 Mar. 1824, in United States Congress, American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1858),  342-343.

properties.name: Bill To Suppress Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Mr. Govan, from the committee to which was referred so much of the President's Message as relates to the suppression of the Slave Trade, reported a bill respecting the slave trade; which was read twice, and committed to a Committee of the Whole," 16 Apr. 1824, in Annals of Congress, 18th Congress, Session 1, 2397–2398.

properties.name: President Monroe's Message On Treaty Of 1824
properties.source: "To the Senate of the United States: Apprehending, from the delay in the decision, that some difficulty exists with the Senate respecting the ratification of the convention lately concluded with the British Government for the suppression of the slave trade," 21 May 1824, in United States Congress, American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1858), 344-346.

properties.name: Great Britain And Sweden Treaty
properties.source: "Treaty between His Britannick Majesty and His Majesty The King of Sweden and Norway for preventing their Subjects from engaging in any Traffick in Slaves," 6 Nov. 1824, in British and Foreign State Papers 1824-1825, (London: James Ridgway and Sons, Piccadilly, 1846), 3-28.

properties.name: Counter Project Of 1825
properties.source: "Mr. Addington to Mr. Adams," 6 Nov. 1824, in United States Congress, American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1858), 367.

properties.name: President Monroe's Message
properties.source: "Fellow Citizens of the Senate, and of the House of Representatives," 7 Dec. 1824, in 18th Congress, Session 2, Documents Accompanying the Message of the President of the United States to Both Houses of Congress at the Commencement of the Second Session of the Eighteenth Congress, (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1824), 2-19.

properties.name: Proposed Treaty With Republic of Colombia
properties.source: "Convention Negotiated with the Republic of Colombia for the Suppression of the African Slave Trade, December 10, 1824, but not Ratified," 21 Feb. 1825, in United States Congress, American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive, of the Congress of the United States (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1858), 729-735.

properties.name: Proposed Resolution on Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That the President of the United States be requested to enter upon, and prosecute from time to time, such negotiations with the several maritime powers of Europe and America, as he may deem expedient for the effectual abolition of the slave trade, and its ultimate denunciation, as piracy, under the law of nations, by the consent of the civilized world," 28 Feb 1825, in Gale and Seaton, Register of Debates, 18th Congress, Session 2, 697, 736.

properties.name: Proposed Resolution Against Right of Search
properties.source: "Resolved, That while this House anxiously desires that the Slave Trade should be, universally, denounced as Piracy, and, as such, should be detected and punished under the law of nations, it considers that it would be highly inexpedient to enter into engagements with any foreign power, by which all the merchant vessels of the United States would be exposed to the inconveniences of any regulation of search, from which any merchant vessels of that foreign power would be exempted," 3 Mar. 1825, in Gale and Seaton, Register of Debates, 18th Congress, Session 2, 739.

properties.name: President Adams's Message
properties.source: "The objects of the West India Squadron have been, to carry into execution the laws for the suppression of the African Slave Trade," 6 Dec. 1825, Official History of the United States by the Presidents: With Historical Reviews of Each Administration (Washington, D.C.: Federal Book Concern, 1900), Vol. I, 164-174.

properties.name: Proposition To Repeal Acts of 1819
properties.source: "Resolved, That it is expedient to repeal so much of the act of the 3d Mar., 1819, entitled, 'An act in addition to the acts prohibiting the slave trade,' as provides for the appointment of agents on the coast of Africa," 14 Feb. 1826, in House Journal, 19th Congress, Session 1, 258.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the support of the navy," 14 Mar. 1826, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 19th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. IV, 140-142.

properties.name: Treaty Between Great Britain and Brazil
properties.source: "Convention between His Majesty and the Emperor of Brazil, for the Abolition of the African Slave Trade," 23 Nov. 1826, in Sir Edward Lewis Hertslet (ed.), A Complete Collection of the Treaties and Conventions and Reciprocal Regulations at Present Subsiting Between Great Britain and Foreign Powers, (London: Law Publishers, 1885),  Vol. III, 33-35.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the support of the Navy,"  in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 19th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. IV, 206-208.

properties.name: Introduction Of Slaves Prohibited
properties.source: "Constitution of the State of Coahuila and Texas," 11 Mar. 1827, in Hans Peter Mareus Neilsen Gammel, The Laws of Texas, 1822-1897, (Austen: The Gammel Book Company, 1898), Vol. I, 423-426.

properties.name: Decree Against Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Decree No. 18," 15 Sep. 1827, in Hans Peter Mareus Neilsen Gammel, The Laws of Texas, 1822-1897, (Austen: The Gammel Book Company, 1898), Vol. I, 78-79.

properties.name: Proposed Bill To Abolish African Agency
properties.source: "A bill to abolish the Agency of the United States on the Coast of Africa, to provide other means of carrying into effect the laws prohibiting the slave trade, and for other purposes," 25 Feb. 1828, in Bills and Resolutions, House of Representatives, 20th Congress, Session 1, H.R. Bill 190.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making an appropriation for the suppression of the slave trade," 24 May 1828, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 19th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. IV, 302.

properties.name: Bill To Amend Act Of 1807
properties.source: "A bill (No. 399) to amend an act, entitled 'An act to prohibit the importation of slaves,'" 28 Jan. 1829, in Bills and Resolutions, House of Representatives, 20th Congress, Session 2, H.R. Bill 399.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making additional appropriations for the support of the navy," 2 Mar. 1829, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 20th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. IV, 353-355.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Act Of Mar. 3, 1819
properties.source: "To amend 'An act in addition to the acts prohibiting the slave trade,'" 7 Apr. 1830, in House Journal, 21th Congress, Session 1, 512.

properties.name: Resolution Against Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That the President of the United States be requested to consult and negotiate with all the Governments where Ministers of the United States are, or shall be accredited, on the means of effecting an entire and immediate abolition of the African slave trade; and especially, on the expediency, with that view, of causing it to be universally denounced as piratical," 7 Apr. 1807, in House Journal, 21th Congress, Session 1, 512.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making a re-appropriation of a sum heretofore appropriated for the suppression of the slave trade," 31 May 1830, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 21th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. IV, 425.

properties.name: Proposed Resolution On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Mr. Mercer moved to suspend the rule of the House in regard to motions, for the purpose of enabling himself to submit a resolution requesting the Executive to enter into negotiations with the maritime Powers of Europe, to induce them to enact laws declaring the African slave trade piracy, and punishing it as such," 16 Feb. 1831, in Gale and Seaton, Register of Debates, House of Representatives, 21st Congress, Session 2, 725.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the naval service," 2 Mar. 1831, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 21th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. IV, 460-462.

properties.name: Resolution As To Treaties
properties.source: "Resolved, That the President of the United States be requested to renew, and to prosecute from time to time, such negotiations with the several maritime powers of Europe and America as he may deem expedient for the effectual abolition of the African slave trade, and its ultimate denunciation as piracy, under the laws of nations, by the consent of the civilized world," 3 Mar. 1831, in House Journal, 21th Congress, Session 2, 426–428.

properties.name: Treaty Granting Right Of Search
properties.source: "Convention between Great Britain and France, for the more effectual suppression of the Traffic in Slaves," 30 Nov. 1831, in British and Foreign State Papers 1830-1831, (London: James Ridgway and Sons, Piccadilly, 1846), 641-644.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the naval service," 20 Feb. 1833, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 22th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. IV, 614-616.

properties.name: Slave-Trade Acts Amended
properties.source: "An Act to reform, amend, and consolidate the penal laws of the State of Georgia," 23 Dec. 1833, in Oliver Hillhouse Prince, A Digest of the Laws of the State of Georgia: Containing All Statutes and the Substance of All Resolutions of a General and Public Nature, and Now in Force, Which Have Been Passed in This State, Previous to the Session of the General Assembly of 1837 (Athens: Oliver Hillhouse Prince, 1837), 653-658.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the naval service," 24 Jan. 1834, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 22th Congress, (Boston: Charles C. Little and James Brown, 1846), Vol. IV, 670-672.

properties.name: Great Britain Slavery Abolition Act
properties.source: "Order in Council, dated 31 July 1835, declaring that adequate and satisfactory Provision has been made by Law in the Islands and Colonies of Antigua, Bermuda, Bahamas, S1. Christopher, Dominica, Grenada, St. Lucia, Trinidad, Mauritius, and the Cape of Good Hope, for giving effect to the Act 3 & 4 Will. IV. c. 73, for the Abolition of Slavery throughout the British Colonies," 31 Jul. 1835, in Great Britain Parliament House of Commons, Accounts and Papers of the House of Commons, (William Clowes and Sons, 1835), Vol. 51, 1-3.

properties.name: African Slave-Trade Prohibited
properties.source: "Constitution of Republic of Texas," 17 Mar. 1836, in Laws of the Republic of Texas, (Houston: Printed at the Office of the Telegraph, 1838), Vol. I, 19.

properties.name: Slave-Trade Made Piracy
properties.source: "An Act supplementary to an act, for the punishment of Crimes and Misdemeanors," 21 Dec. 1836, in Laws of the Republic of Texas, (Houston: Printed at the Office of the Telegraph, 1838), Vol. I, 197-198.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the naval service," 3 Mar. 1837,  in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 24th Congress, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1856), Vol. V, 155-158.

properties.name: Slave-Trade With Texas
properties.source: "Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire whether the present laws of the United States, on the subject of the slave trade, will prohibit that trade being carried on between citizens of the United States and citizens of the Republic of Texas, either by land or by sea," 19 Mar. 1838, in Senate Journal, 25th Congress, Session 2, 297–298, 300.

properties.name: Bill To Amend Slave-Trade Acts
properties.source: "Mr. Strange, on leave, and in pursuance of notice given, introduced a bill to amend an act entitled an act to prohibit the importation of slaves into any port in the jurisdiction of the United States," 5 Feb. 1839, in Senate Journal, 25th Congress, Session 3, 200, 313.

properties.name: President Van Buren's Message
properties.source: "The following message was received from the President of the United States, by Mr. Van Buren, his secretary," 24 Dec. 1839, in House Journal, 26th Congress, Session 1, 15-37.

properties.name: Bill To Amend Act Of 1807
properties.source: "Agreeably to notice, Mr. Strange asked and obtained leave to bring in a bill (Senate, No. 123) to amend an act entitled 'An act to prohibit the importation of slaves into any port or place within the jurisdiction of the United States from and after the 1st day of Jan., in the year 1808,' approved the 2d day of Mar., 1807," 3 Jan. 1840, in Senate Journal, 26th Congress, Session 1, 73, 87, 363.

properties.name: Bill On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Mr. Davis, from the Committee on Commerce, reported a bill (Senate, No. 335) making further provision to prevent the abuse of the flag of the United States, and the use of unauthorized papers in the foreign slavetrade, and for other purposes," 4 May 1840, in House Journal, 26th Congress, Session 1, 1138, 1228, 1257.

properties.name: President Tyler's Message
properties.source: "A communication, in writing, was then received from the President of the United States, by Mr. Robert Tyler, his private Secretary," 1 Jun. 1841, in in House Journal, 26th Congress, Session 1, 22-32.

properties.name: President Tyler's Message
properties.source: "A communication, in writing, was then received from the President of the United States, by Mr. Robert Tyler, his private Secretary," 1 Jun. 1841, in House Journal, 27th Congress, Session 2, 12-25.

properties.name: Quintuple Treaty
properties.source: "Treaty between Great Britain, and Austria, France, Prussia, and Russia, for the Suppression of the African Slave Trade," 20 Dec. 1841, in Great Britain and Lewis Hertslet, A Complete Collection of the Treaties and Conventions, and Reciprocal Regulations at Present Subsisting Between Great Britain and Foreign Powers, and of the Laws, Decrees, and Orders in Council, Concerning the Same; So Far as They Relate to Commerce and Navigation, Repression and Abolition of the Slave Trade; and to the Privileges and Interests of the Subjects of the High Contracting Parties (London: James Bigg and Son, 1845), Vol. VI, 2-20.

properties.name: Right Of Search: Cass's Protest
properties.source: "Mr. Cass to Mr. Webster," 15 Feb. 1842, in James Knox Polk, Message from the President of the United States, Communicating, (In Confidence with Resolutions of the Senate,) Copies of the Correspondence between the Government of the United States and That of Great Britain, on the Subject of the Right of Search; with Copies of the Protest of the American Minister at Paris against the Quintuple Treaty, and the Correspondence Relating Thereto, (House and Senate Documents, 1846), 187-192.

properties.name: Right Of Search: Resolutions On Creole Case
properties.source: "House Doc. No. 215," 26 Feb 1842, in United States Congress House, House Documents, Otherwise Published as Executive Documents: 13th Congress, 2d Session-49th Congress, 1st Session, (Washington, D.C.), Vol. XIII, 990-991.

properties.name: Giddings's Resolutions
properties.source: "§ 5. Resolved, That when a ship belonging to the citizens of any State of this Union leaves the waters and territory of such State, and enters upon the high seas, the persons on board cease to be subject to the slave laws of such State, and therefore are governed in their relations to each other by, and are amenable to, the laws of the United States," 21 Mar. 1842, in House Journal, 27th Congress, Session 2, 567–580.

properties.name: Remonstrance Of Mississippi Against Right Of Search
properties.source: "Mr. Gwin presented resolutions of the Legislature of the State of Mississippi, against granting the right of search to Great Britain for the purpose of suppressing the African slave trade; urging the Government to demand of the British Government redress and restitution in relation to the case of the brig Creole and the slaves on board," 10 May 1842, in House Journal, 27th Congress, Session 2, 800.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the naval service," 4 Aug. 1842, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 27th Congress, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1856), Vol. V, 500-502.

properties.name: Webster-Ashburton Treaty
properties.source: "Webster-Ashburton Treaty," 9 Aug. 1842, in United States and Hunter Miller (eds.), Treaties and Other International Acts of the United States of America: Documents 80-121: 1836-1846, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1934), Vol. IV, 363-370.

properties.name: Joint-Cruising Treaty With Great Britain
properties.source: "Treaty to settle and define boundaries; for the final suppression of the African slave-trade; and for the giving up of criminals fugitive from justice. Concluded Aug. 9, 1842; ratifications exchanged at London Oct. 13, 1842; proclaimed Nov. 10, 1842," 10 Nov. 1842, in the Journal of the Executive Proceedings of the Senate of the United States, 27th Congress, Vol. VI, 118–132.

properties.name: President Tyler's Message
properties.source: "To the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States," 7 Dec. 1842, in John Tyler, Message from the President, to the Congress, at the Commencement of the Third Session of the Twenty-Seventh Congress, House, Dec. 7, 1842, (Washington, D.C.: Gales and Seaton, 1824), 4-16.

properties.name: Appropriation Act Opposed
properties.source: "An Act making appropriations for the naval service for the half calendar year beginning the first day of January and ending the thirtienth day of June, one thousand eight hundred and forty-three," 22 Feb. 1843, in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government in 1789, to March 3, 1845, 27th Congress, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1856), Vol. V, 615-618.

properties.name: President Tyler's Special Message To Congress
properties.source: "Special Message," 20 Feb. 1845, in Edwin Williams (eds.), The Addresses and Messages of the Presidents of the United States, Inaugural, Annual, and Special, from 1789 to 1849: With a Memoir of Each of the Presidents and a History of Their Administrations; Also the Constitution of the United States, and a Selection of Important Documents and Statistical Information (New York: E. Walker, 1849), Vol. II, 1390-1393.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "For carrying into effect the acts for the suppression of the slave trade, including the support of recaptured Africans, and their removal to their country, twenty-five thousand dollars," in Public Statutes at Large of the United States of America from the Organization of the Government from December 1, 1845, to March, 3 1851, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1862), Vol. IX, 85-97.

properties.name: President Taylor's Message
properties.source: "Your attention is earnestly invited to an amendment of our existing laws relating to the African slave-trade, with a view to the effectual suppression of that barbarous traffic. It is not to be denied that this trade is still, in part, carried on by means of vessels built in the United States, and owned or navigated by some of our citizens," 4 Dec. 1849, in James Daniel Richardson, A Compilation of the Messages and Papers of the President, 1789-1908, (Washington, D.C.: Bureau of National Literature and Art, 1909), 9-24.

properties.name: Bill For War Steamers
properties.source: "A bill (House, No. 367) to establish a line of war steamers to the coast of Africa for the suppression of the slave trade and the promotion of commerce and colonization," 1 Aug. 1850, in  Bills and Resolutions, House of Representatives, 31st Congress, Session 1, H.R.367, 1-4.

properties.name: Treaty Of Washington
properties.source: "Mr. Burt, by unanimous consent, introduced a joint resolution (No. 28) 'to terminate the eighth article of the treaty between the United States and Great Britain concluded at Washington the ninth day of Aug., 1842,'" 16 Dec. 1850, in House Journal, 31th Congress, Session 2, 64.

properties.name: Resolution On Sea Letters
properties.source: "Resolved, That the Committee on Commerce be instructed to inquire into the expediency of making more effectual provision by law to prevent the employment of American vessels and American seamen in the African slave trade," 22 Jan. 1851, in Senate Journal, 31st Congress, Session 2, 95, 102–103.

properties.name: Bill On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "A bill (Senate, No. 472) concerning the intercourse and trade of vessels of the United States with certain places on the eastern and western coasts of Africa, and for other purposes," 19 Feb 1851, in Senate Journal, 31st Congress, Session 2, 193-194.

properties.name: Bill To Amend Act Of 1807
properties.source: "A bill to repeal the ninth and tenth sections of the 'Act to prohibit the importation of slaves into any port or place within the jurisdiction of the United States," 3 Dec. 1851, in House Journal, 32nd Congress, Session 1, 42.

properties.name: Illegal Importations
properties.source: "If any slaves, or persons of color, have been or are hereafter brought into this state in violation of the laws of the United States prohibiting the slave trade," 5 Feb. 1852, in Alabama, The Code of Alabama, Prepared by John J. Ormond, Arthur P. Bagby, George Goldthwaite, With Head Notes and Index by Henry C. Semple. Published in Pursuance of an Act of the General Assembly, Approved February 5, 1852 (Montgomery: Brittan and De Wolf, State Printers, 1852), 390-393.

properties.name: Appropriation Proposed
properties.source: "For executing the provisions of the act approved 3d of Mar., 1819, entitled 'An act in addition to the acts prohibiting the slave trade,' $20,000," 3 Mar. 1853, in George Minot, Esq., (ed.), Statutes at Large and Treaties of the United States of America, from December 1, 1851, to March 3, 1855, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1855), Vol. X, 214-219.

properties.name: West India Slave-Trade Bill
properties.source: "Resolved, That the Committee on Foreign Relations be instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing by law for such restrictions on the power of American consuls residing in the Spanish West India islands to issue sea letters on the transfer of American vessels in those islands, as will prevent the abuse of the American flag in protecting persons engaged in the African slave trade," 22 May 1854, in Senate Journal, 33rd Congress, Session 1, 404, 457–458, 472–473, 476.

properties.name: Treaty Of Washington
properties.source: Resolved, "that, in the opinion of the Senate, it is expedient, and in conformity with the interests and sound policy of the United States, that the eighth article of the treaty between this government and Great Britain, of the 9th of Aug., 1842, should be abrogated," 29 May 1854, in Senate Journal, 34th Congress, Session 1-2, 695-698.

properties.name: Bill Regulating Navigation
properties.source: "Mr. Seward asked and obtained leave to bring in a bill (Senate, No. 407) to regulate navigation to the coast of Africa in vessels owned by citizens of the United States, in certain cases; which was read and passed to a second reading," 21 Jun. 1854, in Senate Journal, 33rd Congress, Session 1, 448, 451.

properties.name: Bill For The Suppression Of The Slave-Trade
properties.source: "A bill for the more effectual suppression of the slave trade in American built vessels," 26 Jun. 1854, in Bills and Resolutions, Senate, 33rd Congress, Session 1, 1-4.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Act Of 1818
properties.source: "Mr. Wakeman gave notice, under the rule, of his intention to move for leave to introduce a bill to amend the act to prohibit the introduction or impotation of slaves into any port or place within the jurisdiction of the United States," 23 Jun. 1856, in House Journal, 34th Congress, Session 1, 1101.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making Appropriations for certain Civil Expenses of the Government for the Year ending the thirtienth of June, eighteen hundred and fifty-seven," 18 Aug. 1856, in George Minot and George P Sanger (eds.), Statutes at Large and Treaties of the United States of America, from December 3, 1855, to March 3, 1859, (Boston: Little, Brown, and Company, 1859), Vol. XI, 81-94.

properties.name: South Carolina Governor's Message
properties.source: "It is apprehended that the opening of this trade will lessen the value of slaves, and ultimately destroy the institution," 24 Nov. 1856, in Cluskey, M.W., The Political Text-Book, or Encyclopedia (Philadelphia: J.B. Smith & Co., 1860), 585.

properties.name: Reopening Of The Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That this House of Representatives regards all suggestions and propositions of every kind, by whomsoever made, for a revival of the African slave trade, as shocking to the moral sentiment of the enlightened portion of mankind," 15 Dec. 1856, in House Journal, 34th Congress, Session 3, 105-111.

properties.name: Reopening Of The Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That it is inexpedient to repeal the laws prohibiting the African slave trade," 15 Dec. 1856, in Congressional Globe, 34th Congress, Session 3, 123.

properties.name: Reopening Of The Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That it is inexpedient, unwise, and contrary to the settled policy of the United States, to repeal the laws prohibiting the African slave trade," 15 Dec. 1856, in Congressional Globe, 34th Congress, Session 3, 125-126.

properties.name: Minority Special Report Of Legislative Committee
properties.source: Edward B. Bryan et al., Report of the Special Committee of the House of Representatives, of South Carolina, on so much of the Message of His Excellency Gov. Jas. H. Adams, as relates to Slavery and the Slave Trade (Columbia: Steam Power Press of Walker, Evans & Co., 1857), 1-40.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making Appropriations for certain Civil Expenses of the Government for the Year ending the thirtienth of June, eighteen hundred and fifty-eight," 3 Mar. 1857, in George Minot and George P Sanger (eds.), Statutes at Large and Treaties of the United States of America, from December 3, 1855, to March 3, 1859, (Boston: Little, Brown, and Company, 1859), Vol. XI, 221-230.

properties.name: Bill To Import Africans
properties.source: "We know that the revival of the slave trade is earnestly demanded by the more active spirits of the South," Mar. 1858, in Congressional Globe, 35th Congress, Session 1, 1362.

properties.name: President Buchanan's Message
properties.source: "Message of the President of the United States," 6 Dec. 1858, in  Congressional Globe, 35th Congress, Session 1, 1-9.

properties.name: Resolution On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That the Committee on Naval Affairs be requested to inquire and report to this House if any, and what, further legislation is necessary on the part of the United States to fully carry out and perform the stipulations contained in the eighth article of the treaty with Great Britain (known as the 'Ashburton treaty') for the suppression of the slave trade," 23 Dec. 1858, in House Journal, 35th Congress, Session 2, 115-116.

properties.name: Resolution On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary inquire whether any amendments to existing laws ought to be made for the suppression of the African slave trade," 5 Jan. 1859, in Senate Journal, 35th Congress, Session 2, 80, 108, 115.

properties.name: Bill on Slave-Trade
properties.source: "[..]a bill (Senate, No. 510) in addition to the acts which prohibit the slave trade," 13 Jan. 1859, in Senate Journal, 35th Congress, Session 2, 134, 321.

properties.name: Reopening Of The Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Whereas the laws prohibiting the African slave trade have become a topic of discussion with newspaper writers and political agitators, many of them boldly denouncing these laws as unwise in policy and disgraceful in their provisions, and insisting on the justice and propriety of their repeal, and the revival of the odious traffic in African slaves," 31 Jan. 1859, in House Journal, 35th Congress, Session 2, 298-299.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making Appropriations for the Naval Service for the Year ending the thirtienth of June, eight hunred and sixty," 3 Mar. 1859, in George Minot and George P Sanger (eds.), Statutes at Large and Treaties of the United States of America, from December 3, 1855, to March 3, 1859, (Boston: Little, Brown, and Company, 1859), Vol. XI, 404.

properties.name: President Buchanan's Message
properties.source: "Message of the President of the United States," 19 Dec. 1859, in Congressional Globe, 36th Congress, Session 1, 1-7.

properties.name: Proposed Resolution
properties.source: "Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the laws of the United States in relation to the suppression of the African slave trade as to provide a penalty of imprisonment for life for a participation in such trade, instead of the penalty of forfeiture of life, as now provided," 20 Mar. 1860, in Senate Journal, 36th Congress, Session 1, 274.

properties.name: Right Of Search
properties.source: "Mr. Wilson asked, and by unanimous consent obtained, leave to bring in a joint resolution (Senate, No. 20) to secure the right of search on the coast of Africa, for the more effectual suppression of the African slave trade," 20 Mar. 1860, in Senate Journal, 36th Congress, Session 1, 274.

properties.name: Steam Vessels For Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Mr. Wilson asked, and by unanimous consent obtained, leave to bring in a bill (Senate, No. 296) for the construction of five steam screw sloops-of-war, for service on the African coast," 20 Mar. 1860, in Senate Journal, 36th Congress, Session 1, 494-495.

properties.name: Proposed Resolutions
properties.source: "Resolved, That for the more effectual suppression of the African slave trade the treaty of 1842," 26 Mar. 1860, in House Journal, 36th Congress, Session 1, 588-589.

properties.name: Bill On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Mr. Wilson asked, and by unanimous consent obtained, leave to bring in a bill (Senate, No. 408) for the more effectual suppression of the slave trade," 16 Apr. 1860, in Senate Journal, 36th Congress, Session 1, 394, 485.

properties.name: Buyers Of Imported Slaves
properties.source: "Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to report forthwith a bill providing that any person purchasing any negro or other person imported into this country in violation of the laws for suppressing the slave trade, shall not by reason of said purchase acquire any title to said negro or person," 21 May 1860, in House Journal, 36th Congress, Session 1, 880.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making Appropriations for the Construction of certain military Roads in the Territory of Washington," 26 May 1860, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 19-21.

properties.name: Additional Act To Act Of 1819
properties.source: "An Act to amend an Act entitled 'An Act in addition to the Acts Prohibiting the Slave Trade,'" 16 Jun. 1860, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 40-41.

properties.name: Proposed Cooperation
properties.source: "Correspondence between the English and American Governments on the subject or the Slave-Trade," 11 Jul. 1860, in The African Repository and Colonial Journal, (Washington: C. Alexander, 1860), Vol. XXXVI, 303-306.

properties.name: President Buchanan's Message
properties.source: "Message of the President of the United States," 3 Dec. 1860, in Congressional Globe, 36th Congress, Session 2, 1-7.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Constitution
properties.source: "The migration or importation of slaves into the United States or any of the Territories thereof, from any foreign country, is hereby prohibited," 12 Dec. 1860, in House Journal, 36th Congress, Session 2, 61-62.

properties.name: Bill On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Mr. Wilson asked, and by unanimous consent obtained, leave to bring in a bill (Senate, No. 529) for the more effectual suppression of the slave trade," 24 Dec. 1860, in Senate Journal, 36th Congress, Session 2, 62.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Constitution
properties.source: "A joint resolution providing for amendments to the Constitution of the United States," 7 Jan. 1861, in Congressional Globe, 36th Congress, Session 2, 279.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Constitution
properties.source: "Neither Congress nor a Territorial Legislature shall make any law respecting slavery or involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime; but Congress may pass laws for the suppression of the African slave trade, and the rendition of fugitives from service or labor in the States," 23 Jan. 1861, in Congressional Globe, 36th Congress, Session 2, 527.

properties.name: Proposition To Amend Constitution
properties.source: "The migration or importation of persons held to service or involuntary servitude into any State, Territory, or place within the United States, from any place or country beyond the limits of the United States or Territories thereof, is forever prohibited," 1 Feb. 1861, in Congressional Globe, 36th Congress, Session 2, 1243.

properties.name: Confederate States Of America: Importation Prohibited
properties.source: "Constitution for the Provisional Government of the Confederate States of America," 8 Feb. 1861, in Confederate States of America, The Statutes at Large of the Provisional Government of the Confederate States of America: From the Institution of the Government, February 8, 1861 to Its Termination, February 18, 1862, (Richmond: R. M. Smith, 1864), 1-8.

properties.name: Confederate States Of America: Statutory Prohibition
properties.source: "Be it enacted by the Confederate States of America in Congress assembled, That all the laws of the United States of America in force and in use in the Confederate States of America on the first day of Nov. last, and not inconsistent with the Constitution of the Confederate States, be and the same are hereby continued in force until altered or repealed by the Congress," 9 Feb. 1861, in Confederate States of America, The Statutes at Large of the Provisional Government of the Confederate States of America: From the Institution of the Government, February 8, 1861 to Its Termination, February 18, 1862, (Richmond: R. M. Smith, 1864), 27.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act to supply Deficiencies in the Appropriations for the Service of the fiscal Year ending June thirtienth, eighteen hundred and sixty-one," 19 Feb. 1861, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 131-133.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act for making Appropriations for sundry Civil Expenses of the Government for the Year ending June thirty, eighteen hundred and sixty-two," 2 Mar. 1861, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 214-220.

properties.name: President Lincoln's Message
properties.source: "Message of the President of the United States," in Abraham Lincoln, Message of the President of the United States to the two Houses of Congress at the commencement of the second session of the Thirty-seventh Congress. Senate, Dec. 3, 1861. 37th Congress, 2nd Session, (Washington: Government Printing Office, 1861), 3-20.

properties.name: Bill On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Agreeably to notice Mr. Wilson, of Massachusetts, asked and obtained leave to bring in a bill (Senate, No. 173), for the more effectual suppression of the slave trade," 27 Jan. 1862, in Senate Journal, 37th Congress, Session 2, 143.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "An Act making Appropriations for the Legislature, Executive, and Judicial Expenses of the Government for the Year ending the thirtienth of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-three," 14 Mar. 1862, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 355-369.

properties.name: Prize Law
properties.source: "An Act to facilitate Judicial Proceedings in Adjudications upon Captured Property, and for the better Administration of the Law of Prize," 25 Mar. 1862, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 374-375.

properties.name: Treaty Of 1862
properties.source: "Treaty for the suppression of the African slave trade," 7 Jun. 1862, in Senate Executive Journal, 37th, Session 2, Vol. XII, 230, 231, 240, 254, 391, 400, 403.

properties.name: Treaty Of 1862 Carried Into Effect
properties.source: "An Act to carry into Effect the Treaty between the United States and her Britannic Majesty for the Suppression of the African Slave-Trade," 11 Jul. 1862, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 531.

properties.name: Former Acts Amended
properties.source: "An Act to amend an Act entitled 'An Act to amend an Act entitled 'An Act in Addition to the Acts prohibiting the Slave Trade,'" 17 Jul. 1862, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 592-593.

properties.name: Appropriations Act
properties.source: "An Act for making Appropriations for the Consular and Diplomatic Expenses of the Government for the Year ending June thirtienth, eighteen hundred and sixty-four," in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 638-639.

properties.name: Joint Resolution
properties.source: "Joint Resolution respecting the Compensation of the Judges and so forth, under the Treaty with Great Britain and other Persons employed in the Suppression of the Slave Trade," 3 Mar. 1863, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America from December 5, 1859, to March 3, 1863, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1863), Vol. XII, 829.

properties.name: Treaty Of 1862 Amended
properties.source: “Additional Article to the Treaty with Great Britain for Suppression of the African Slave Trade, Message of the President,” 22 Apr. 1863, in Message of the President of the United states, 37th Congress, Session 3, (Washington: Government Printing Office, 1863).

properties.name: Resolution On Coastwise Slave-Trade
properties.source: "Coastwise Slave Trade," 17 Dec. 1863, in Congressional Globe, 38th Congress, Session 1, 46.

properties.name: Coastwise Slave-Trade Prohibited Forever
properties.source: "An Act making Appropriations for sundry Civil Expenses of the Government for the Year ending the Thirtienth of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, and for other purposes," 2 Jul. 1864, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America, from December 1863, to December 1865, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1866), Vol. XIII, 344-354.

properties.name: International Proposition
properties.source: "The crime of trading in human beings has been for many years branded by the reprobation of all civilized nations. Still the atrocious traffic subsists, and many persons flourish on the gains they have derived from that polluted source," 7 Dec. 1864, in Great Britain Parliament House of Commons, Accounts and Papers of the House of Commons (Ordered by the House of Commons to be printed, 1865), Vol. XXXV, 47.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "Commercial Agencies, Schedule C," 24 Jan. 1865, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America, from December 1863, to December 1865, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1866), Vol. XIII, 423-424.

properties.name: Compensation To Marshals, Etc.
properties.source: "An Act making additional Appropriations, and to supply the Deficiencies in the Appropriations for sundry Civil Expenses of the Government for the fiscal Year ending the thirtienth of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, and for other purposes," 7 Apr. 1866, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America, from December 1865, to December 1867, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1868), Vol. XIV, 14-26.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "Commercial Agencies, Schedule C," 25 Jun. 1866, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America, from December 1865, to December 1867, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1868), Vol. XIV,  225-226.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "Commercial Agencies, Schedule C," 28 Feb. 1867, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America, from December 1865, to December 1867, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1868), Vol. XIV,  414-415.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "Commercial Agencies, Schedule C," 30 Mar. 1868, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America, from December 1867, to December 1869, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1869), Vol. XV, 57-58.

properties.name: Abrogation of Treaty of 1862
properties.source: "Whereas the slave trade has been practically suppressed," 6 Jan. 1869, in Congressional Globe, 40th Congress, Session 3, 224.

properties.name: Appropriation Act
properties.source: "Commercial Agencies, Schedule C," 3 Mar. 1869, in The Statutes at Large, Treaties, and Proclamations, of the United States of America, from December 1867, to December 1869, (Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1869), Vol. XV, 320-322.

properties.name: Bill To Repeal Act Of 1803
properties.source: "(S. No. 251) to repeal an act entitled 'An act to prevent the importation of certain persons into certain States where by the laws thereof their admission is prohibited,'" 22 Apr. 1870, in Congressional Globe, 41th Congress, Session 2, 2894, 2932, 4953, 5594.

properties.name: Additional Treaty
properties.source: "Additional convention to the treaty of Apr. 7, 1862, respecting the African slave trade," 16 Sep. 1870, in Treaties and Conventions Concluded between the United States of America and Other Powers since Jun. 4, 1776, (Washington: Government Printing Office, 1889), 472-476.

properties.name: Bill On Slave-Trade
properties.source: "A bill (House, No. 490) to carry into effect article thirteen of the Constitution of the United States, and to prohibit the owning or dealing in slaves by American citizens in foreign countries," 11 Dec. 1871, in House Journal, 42th Congress, Session 2, 48.
